stem: A 22-year-old had an ORIF of the left tibia 6 hours ago. He reports severe pain (10/10) that is unrelieved by Morphine. The left foot is cold with a faint pedal pulse. Complete the bowtie to guide care.

actions.text: Bivalve or remove the restrictive cast/dressing
Position the limb at the level of the heart
Apply ice packs and elevate the limb above the heart

parameters.text: Pain level and response to analgesics

rationale.correct: Pain out of proportion to injury + pain with passive stretch = Compartment Syndrome. Priority is decompression (removing restriction) and notifying the surgeon for a possible fasciotomy. The limb should NOT be elevated above the heart (reduces perfusion).
rationale.incorrect: Elevation and ice both worsen ischemia in compartment syndrome. Calcium and WBC are irrelevant.
clinicalPearls: The first sign is usually pain; the last sign is loss of pulses (Necrosis).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: In compartment syndrome, keep the limb at heart level. Elevating it further decreases arterial inflow to the high-pressure tissue.
